objects.title: CodeArena
objects.summary: A competitive auditing platform for Smart Contract Auditors to review smart contracts that are close to production deployement. There are incentives to finding High/Medium/Low vulernabilities as well as QA/Informational findings. Reports are often published after an audit has been completed and patched, allowing for further learning for the auditors on the platform.
bulletPoints: Finished in the top 500 for the year of 2022
Found a medium severity finding during the Forgotten Runes audit competition

objects.title: That Time I Found a Critical Web3 Bug
objects.summary: After witnessing countless protocols and projects get exploited by hackers, I decided to finally jump into the world of smart contract security. Luckily enough, one of the NFT projects that I was an active member of were starting a bug bounty for their next phase of the roadmap.
bulletPoints: Gained a mastery of the protocol after reading through every line of the new contracts
Reported a critical vulnerability that was accepted
Vulnerability would have lead to stolen of users' NFTs

objects.title: Read the Signs: The dangers of eth_sign
objects.summary: After almost falling victim to a fake Collab.Land bot, I dug deep into the Metamask source code and ventured into EIPs to understand how hacks similar to this can drain the wallets of unsuspecting users who approve a signature.
bulletPoints: Made a proof-of-concept of the attack
Reverse engineered an attack that uses raw eth_sign signatures in order to trick a user into signing a transaction that they don't know is harmful if approved
Dove into the Metamask source code, EIP 1559 and EIP 2718 to understand how transactions were created

objects.title: ERC721A's Hidden Reentrancy Prevention
objects.summary: If you have been an NFT degen for the past couple months, you probably have heard about the hot off-shoot of the ERC721 standard called ERC721A which was developed and open sourced by Chiru Labs. It is widely known for its gas optimizations that helps to bring down the cost of minting down but after a late night of research and a failed attempt of finding bugs in an NFT contract I found a small feature that I didn't see being talked about when ERC721A was first introduced so thought to write about it because it's pretty cool.
bulletPoints: Researched into the anatomy of re-entrancy attacks
Attained a deeper understanding of the ERC721A standard
Created tests in Foundry to prove that the re-entrancy protection works

objects.title: Rest And Reps
objects.summary: Going to the gym is one of my favorite hobbies. So, when I noticed that I was taking too much time to rest in between exercises the idea came to mind to make an app to solve that!
bulletPoints: Gained a basic knowledge of Flutter Development
Have the ability to make custom workouts and save them locally to the user's device

objects.title: Web3 Projects
objects.summary: Web3 had been a topic with growing interest, atleast in the bullrun, for many people. As I got deeper into the NFT craze, I found myself wanting to learn more about Web3 developement if it indeed was going to be the next phase of the internet. To help me explore that, I made a few tiny projects to gain a deeper understanding of Web3 developement.
bulletPoints: Dead man's Switch — A password to a file would be stored on the blockchain which therefore made it immutable. A user would have to keep the switch active to prevent that password from being able to be read by anyone.
Nordle — Worlde but on-chain and can be represented by NFTs
Verify Signature — A small website to create and/or verify the signature made by an Ethereum EOA
NFT Minting Bot — Automatically mint NFTs by creating a raw signature that executes once a trigger on the smart contract is activated
objects.techStack: React, Metamask, ethers.js, CSS, HTML, javascript
